title: Hatching Chick

verbs: To avoid as a result of fear.
nouns: Warm-blooded egg-laying vertebrates characterized by feathers and forelimbs modified as wings
Birds are feathered, winged, two-legged, warm-blooded, egg-laying vertebrates.
Any of the bipedal, warm-blooded vertebrates that lay eggs having wings which, for most species, enables them to fly.
Feathered, winged, bipedal, endothermic, egg-laying, vertebrate animal
Birds are bipedal, warm-blooded, oviparous vertebrate animals characterized primarily by feathers, forelimbs modified as wings, and hollow bones.
A member of the class of animals Aves in the phylum Chordata, characterized by being warm-blooded, having feathers and wings usually capable of flight, and laying eggs.
Duck is the common name for a large number of species in the Anatidae family of birds, which also includes swans and geese.
Common name for many species in the bird family Anatidae
Small wild or domesticated web-footed broad-billed swimming bird usually having a depressed body and short legs
Domesticated fowl, primarily a source of food
The flesh of a chicken used for food
The flesh of the domesticated chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus).
The chicken is a domesticated fowl, a subspecies of the Red Junglefowl.
Chickens are a domesticated fowl, a subspecies of the Red Junglefowl.
A hen; a cooked chicken; a chicken dressed for cooking.
A domestic fowl, Gallus gallus, especially when young

description:
A baby chicken (chick), hatching from an egg and seeing the world for the first time. Depicted as a yellow chick with an orange beak facing forward in the cracked, bottom half of a white egg, generally shown flapping its wings with a cute facial expression.

Often used with an affectionate tone. May be used to represent various types of baby birds. May also be used to represent chicken foods (e.g., poultry, eggs), spring, Easter, or slang senses of chick.

Not to be confused with üê§ Baby Chick or üê•Front-Facing Baby Chick (out of its egg), though their applications overlap. See also üêî Chicken and üêì Rooster.

Twitter and Facebook's designs do not include wings. Google's design previously featured motion lines around the chick's wings, indicating flapping. Facebook's design previously showed part of the egg atop the chick's head.
apple_vendor_description: The hatching chick emoji on Apple devices emerges with delightful realism, showing a small, fluffy chick just breaking free from its shell. Apple's characteristic soft rounded edges and smooth gradients give the chick a tender appearance, with realistic lighting catching its downy feathers. This emoji symbolizes new beginnings, innocence, and the anticipation of growth, bringing a sense of gentle optimism to conversations on Apple devices.
